title: Shoppers splurging on pumpkins weeks before Halloween but not yet stockpiling for Brexit
text:
Shoppers are stocking up on Halloween pumpkins early this year, with £1.5million already spent on the spooky orange vegetable at supermarkets in the past 12 weeks.

That's nearly 30 per cent higher than this time last year, according to the latest grocery data from Kantar, as more UK households appear to get involved with the annual event.

Meanwhile, the study found no clear-cut evidence that shoppers are stockpiling food ahead of a possible no-deal Brexit.

Shoppers are stocking up on Halloween pumpkins early this year, with £1.5million spent in supermarkets in the past 12 weeks

While sales of dry pasta and healthcare products over the past four weeks rose 9 per cent and 7 per cent, those of canned products fell by 2 per cent and frozen food by 1 per cent.

Shoppers are seemingly 'waiting to see how the next few weeks play out', Kantar's Fraser McKevitt said.

While sales of dry pasta and healthcare products over the past four weeks rose 9% and 7%, those of canned products fell by 2%

He explained that concerns around the availability of some foods in the event of a no-deal on October 31st have 'not yet translated into a consistent increase in purchasing'.

But he warned that could change in the coming days and weeks, depending on the progress of negotiations.

'While a quarter of British consumers say they are considering stockpiling, it seems they are waiting to see how the next few weeks play out, and we expect if they take any action, it will be closer to the deadline if a chaotic trading situation looks increasingly likely,' McKevitt said.

Across the whole grocery sector, supermarket sales grew 1.3 per cent in the past three months - a sign that the market has 'finally edged out from under the shadow' of last year's bumper summer.

Chart from Kantar shows supermarket sales over the past 12 weeks, with Sainsbury's nudging up 0.6% year-on-year

Of the so-called 'Big Four' supermarkets - Tesco, Sainsbury's, Asda and Morrisons - the only firm to grow sales during the period was Sainsbury's.

Tesco, Asda and Morrisons all improved their performance month-on-month, but sales are still down year-on-year. Morrisons was at the back of the pack with a decline of 1.8 per cent.

Meanwhile, the march of the discounters rolled on, with Lidl and Aldi cumulatively accounting for 14 per cent of all UK grocery sales during the period.

That marks a 0.8 per cent annual increase, equivalent to nearly £1billion.
